audio_description: Assalamu Alaikum dear Dastarkhwan! A heartfelt welcome to all my loving viewers and subscribers. Today I’m sharing with you the recipe for an amazing chicken biryani from Kolkata’s Bengali-area shop. Just by looking at it, you can tell it’s a total hit—so flavorful and rich. You must make it, and when you do, you won’t just make one—because it’s that good.

audio_description: The Kolkata Bengali-area shop biryani is known for its deep dark‑brown color. It isn’t made with brown food color. So try making this biryani once—you’ll be astonished at how superb it turns out at home. Let’s quickly get into the recipe.

audio_description: To make the biryani, I’m taking 300 g mustard oil. Once it gets hot, reduce the flame to medium and add 150 g finely chopped onions. Fry them until golden and crispy—that’s your birista. The oil needs to be hot and, on medium flame, fry until birista forms well.

audio_description: Now in the same oil, fry the potatoes. The Kolkata Bengali‑area shop biryani uses this method. Fry the potatoes on medium flame until the color changes nicely. I’ll also show how to test—poke with a knife, and if it goes in without the potato falling apart, it’s about 80% cooked.

audio_description: … (Omitted repeated filler lines.)

Use plenty of oil for this biryani—it makes Kolkata biryani rich. As you fry potatoes and onions, the oil level drops. Now add 150 g onions and fry them. With the onions, add 2 bay leaves, 3 small green cardamoms, 2 large cardamoms, 10–12 cloves, and 2–3 cinnamon sticks.

audio_description: Fry the onions until very dark brown. Kolkata Bengali‑area shop biryani deliberately avoids food color—relying instead on dark‑fried onions for the beautiful brown hue on potatoes and chicken, and later on the rice. You’ll taste it when you try it!

audio_description: If you’ve eaten Kolkata biryani in restaurants or weddings, you’ll notice the meat pieces are large—that gives a deeper taste. Because Kolkata biryani is made with yakhni (meat broth), you want big pieces that won’t break during dum.

audio_description: After adding the yogurt, stir well—add nothing else—and cook covered on medium flame for 15 minutes. At that point, you’ll see the bones emerging from the chicken—then you know it's ready. Don’t use small pieces, or the chicken may fall apart during dum. We use large chunks for that reason. Remove all the meat pieces and strain the yakhni (broth). If it seems too much, dry it by simmering 5–6 minutes high flame. The broth will thicken nicely.

audio_description: Yakhni is ready. Strain out the spices—don’t use them further—they’ve imparted their flavor to the broth. I poured about two cups of yakhni. Now add ½ cup warm milk (not hot) and 1 tsp sugar—to balance the flavors. Also add 1 Tbsp biryani masala—the one used in Bengali‑area restaurant/wedding style—which I've uploaded on my channel; see the link in description. Add juice of one lemon—its flavor is excellent.

audio_description: After mixing the yakhni with the potatoes and chicken, we add them. The taste comes from cooked rice that’s only 70–75% done—the broth makes the rice perfect with dum steam. Then add the previously fried potatoes and birista (fried onions) over the mixture. I can’t explain the aroma; you must make it. I’m also adding 50 g mawa (khoa)—available at sweet shops and dairies—to enrich it. Cover and set aside.

audio_description: This is the top-quality Bengali-area shop biryani, replicable at home. Now, to serve, we first scoop rice to one side, then place chicken or potatoes on the rice, then carefully layer the rest—this ensures oily bottom favorites go to those who want them, while the top stays lighter. That’s why Kolkata biryani is rich and layered.
